content.text: Git LFS
What is Git LFS?
Git LFS (Large File Storage) is an extension for Git that helps you manage large files (like videos, images, or datasets) efficiently.
content.html: Git LFS (Large File Storage) is an extension for Git that helps you manage large files (like videos, images, or datasets) efficiently.

content.text: Instead of storing big files directly in your repository, LFS stores a small pointer file in your repo and keeps the real content on a separate LFS server.
content.html: Instead of storing big files directly in your repository, LFS stores a small pointer file in your repo and keeps the real content on a separate LFS server.

content.text: This keeps your repository fast and small, even if you work with huge files.
content.html: This keeps your repository fast and small, even if you work with huge files.

content.text: Everyone who clones the repo gets the pointer, and Git LFS fetches the real file content as needed.
content.html: Everyone who clones the repo gets the pointer, and Git LFS fetches the real file content as needed.

content.text: When to Use Git LFS
Install Git LFS

content.code_html: git lfs install

content.text: Track Files with LFS

content.code_html: git lfs track "*.psd"

content.text: You can track any file type. Here are more examples:
content.html: You can track any file type. Here are more examples:

content.code:
git
lfs track
"*.zip"


git
lfs track
"data/*.csv"


git
lfs track
"images/*.{png,jpg}"
content.code_html:
git lfs track "*.zip"
git lfs track "data/*.csv"
git lfs track "images/*.{png,jpg}"

content.text: How LFS Works (.gitattributes & Pointers)
When you track a file type with LFS, Git adds a rule to the .gitattributes file. This tells Git to use LFS for those files.
content.html: When you track a file type with LFS, Git adds a rule to the .gitattributes file. This tells Git to use LFS for those files.

content.code_html: *.psd filter=lfs diff=lfs merge=lfs -text

content.text: When you add and commit a tracked file, Git stores a small "pointer" file in your repo. The real content is uploaded to the LFS server.
content.html: When you add and commit a tracked file, Git stores a small "pointer" file in your repo. The real content is uploaded to the LFS server.

content.text: If you clone or pull a repo with LFS files, Git will download the real content from the LFS server (if you have LFS installed).
content.html: If you clone or pull a repo with LFS files, Git will download the real content from the LFS server (if you have LFS installed).

content.text: Add, Commit, and Push LFS Files
The actual file data is stored on the LFS server, while your repo contains a pointer file.
content.html: The actual file data is stored on the LFS server, while your repo contains a pointer file.

content.text: Check LFS Status
See which files are managed by LFS in your repo:
content.html: See which files are managed by LFS in your repo:

content.code_html: git lfs ls-files

content.text: Untrack/Remove Files from LFS

content.code_html:
git lfs untrack "*.psd"
git add .gitattributes

content.text: Commit the change. The file will no longer be managed by LFS (but existing versions are still stored in LFS).
content.html: Commit the change. The file will no longer be managed by LFS (but existing versions are still stored in LFS).
